description: The Yemeni Ministry of Education, which is under the authority of the Houthis in Sana'a, announced the closure of all schools for one week starting March 15th. UPDATE: The original plan was to end the school year starting March 16th but still have final exams on March 21st. The new policy imposes the closure of schools for one week (meaning until March 22nd).
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, the Security Belt Forces have imposed a curfew in Aden from 22:00-06:00 as of March 26th, until further notice.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Local authorities in Yemen’s Hadramout province have imposed a curfew from 4p.m. on April 2nd to 4 a.m. on April 3rd, provided that personnel working in medical and health care would be exempt from this curfew.

In Yemen,the Governor of the Hadhramaut province imposed a curfew in Al-Sheher, Al-Days, Al-Sharqiyah, Al-Raida and Qsaye'r from eight in the morning on April 10 until six in the morning on Saturday, April 11 after the official announcement of the first case of the new Corona virus in Al-Sheher city.
On April 10, local authorities in Yemen’s Hadramout province have imposed an indefinite curfew in place from 16:00 to 04:00 (local time) in all major cities in Hadhramaut.

On May 5, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) announced a partial curfew from 10 p.m. to 12 p.m. in Aden and the two governorates under its control (Lahj and Al-Dhale) for three weeks, starting May 6. All international organizations operating in STC-controlled governorates are excluded from the curfew, as are health care workers and employees of gas stations and hotels, on a limited basis.
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 24, regional authorities in Yemen's Marib province imposed a curfew between the hours of 18:00 and 05:00 (local time) from Sunday, May 24 until further notice.
Yemen has implemented health screenings at the airport and at the borders to detect travelers exhibiting nCoV symptoms.
Non-Yemeni nationals with recent travel to China maybe refused admission in the country.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Yemen has announced the temporary suspension of work visas for any foreign citizen coming from countries where the virus is widely spread, unless they provide evidence that they were not infected with the Coronavirus.
target_who_what: All Foreign Nationals (Foreign Residents + Foreign Travelers)

description: Non-Yemeni travelers must disclose whether they have visited Iran or any other country where the virus is heavily spread - in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Yemen.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Yemen requires all carriers - including United Nations Humanitarian Air Service and all companies that ensure public land transports - to fill out a form disclosing recent travels upon arrival at the airports and ports of the Republic of Yemen.
The High Ministerial Committee for Combating Epidemics decided to close land outlets for a period of two weeks, starting March 16, with the exception of goods and freight.

In Yemen, the Corporation of Aden Gulf Seaports announced the implementation of precautionary measures to control the coronavirus, including checking all ships prior docking at the harbor, all sailors and crews should stay on the ships until being checked and make sure they proved negative coronavirus tests.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Yemeni government suspends all flights - domestic and international - to and from airports under its control for two weeks starting on March 18, with an exemption of flights for humanitarian purposes. The key airports his government controls are in Aden, Sayoun and Mukalla.

In Yemen, the Higher Ministerial Committee for Epidemic Control renewed the temporary suspension of flights arriving to Sanaa International Airport until the end of April. UPDATE: The temporary suspension of flights was extended until the end of April. The original flight suspension was set to last until April 1st.
The Yemeni government closes border with Saudi Arabia (Al-Wadia border) over COVID-19 concerns on April 8.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On May 5, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) ordered the continued closure of land ports in Aden, allowing only essential goods such as food, fuel and relief items to pass.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, anyone exhibiting NCoV symptoms may be subjected to NCoV testing.

In Yemen, the Technical Committee for Combating Coronavirus in Sanaa province approved the equipment of four isolation centers in the province and instructed the Finance Office to equip two hotels for quarantine in the province to face any emergency.

In Yemen, training course was held on March 18 in Sana'a in the field of preparedness to face the coronavirus. It was organized by the Ministry of Public Health and Population in cooperation with the Preventive Medicine Division of the Ministry of Defense. There were 65 trainees.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 21st, the Yemeni Health Ministry confirmed the mobilization of 18 hospitals in the country where health supplies will be prepared and the health personnel will be trained.
On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to limit the work of public and private hospitals to receiving emergency cases and emergency operations.
On May 5, the Higher Ministerial Committee for Combating Epidemics said it would establish a field hospital in the capital with a capacity of 3,000 beds to deal with coronavirus patients.
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7, a training course on precautionary measures to confront Corona was launched on in the Yemeni province of Taiz. 120 health professionals were trained on the symptoms of the virus, isolation, quarantine, and ways to combat the virus.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On May 7, a training course on precautionary measures to confront Corona was launched on in the Yemeni province of Taiz. It ended on May 10. 120 health professionals were trained on the symptoms of the virus, isolation, quarantine, and ways to combat the virus. UPDATE: The training ended on May 10th.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On May 18, a five-day training course on precautionary measures for confronting Covid-19 was held inthe Yemeni province Amran. It included 150 trainees and was organized by World Health Organization and the World Bank in cooperation with the health official in the province.
On May 24, the Yemeni national coronavirus committee released a list of hotels approved as quarantine locations.
On June 11, the Yemeni Minister of Public Health and Population and the Governor of Ibb province opened the health isolation hospital in al-Sahol area.
On June 14, the Public Health and Population Office in the Yemeni province of Taiz organized three-day training courses for health workers in the field of immunization in partnership with the UNICEF.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, the Ministry of Civil Service and Insurance announced the suspension of the fingerprint system in all units of the state’s administrative apparatus, the public and mixed sectors, and the private sector for a month as of March 16th.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, the Higher Ministerial Committee for Epidemic Control imposed the provision of sterilization tools in all government facilities by the local authorities.

In Yemen, the Ministry of Civil Service and Insurance announced that the suspension of the fingerprint system in all units of the state’s administrative apparatus will end on June 14th. UPDATE: The end of the policy was set for June 14th.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen announced that the Ministry of Public Works, and the local authorities in the capital Sanaa, and the provinces should spray sterilizers and disinfectants at the entrances to cities and lanes.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to tighten the control of the cleanliness of public baths by providing disinfectants and sterilizers.

On March 23, Yemeni Communications Minister Muammar Al-Aryani issued a decree prohibiting the publication and circulation of print newspapers (governmental and private) in the country from March 25 to April 12 to limit the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 10, the Yemeni governorate of Hadramawat ordered the closure of Ash Shihr port where the first coronavirus case was recorded for a week for sterilization

On April 10, the Yemeni governorate of Hadramawat announced the implementation of a campaign to spray and sterilize public places, streets and public markets by the hygiene fund and the use of fire trucks for spraying and sterilization during the curfew implemented in the eastern districts.
On April 11,  the Yemeni province of Taiz started a process of spraying and sterilization of markets and shops.

On May 6, Houthi authorities in Yemen ordered field teams to conduct a sterilization campaign in Sanaa during the 24-hour closure of all mosques and select neighborhoods in areas of the capital under their control.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 11, a spraying and sterilizations campaign was launched in the Yemeni province of Ibb, including streets, markets, security points and public facilities in the province.

On May 31st, The Technical Committee to confront Corona in the Yemeni province of Hajjah announced the activation of spraying and sterilization campaigns in all neighborhoods, streets, markets, mosques, public centers and private facilities.
In Yemen, the National Salvation Government called citizens to reduce movement between provinces, districts and cities, except for necessity only, for a period of 2 weeks as of March 22.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, the Ministry of Interior decided to prevent citizens from moving between the governorates controlled by the internationally recognized government and from/to governorates under Houthi control as of March 26 until further notice.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 10,  the Yemeni governorate of Al Mahra ordered the security forces to close the borders with the province of Hadhramout.
On April 10, the Yemeni governorate of Hadramaout decided to ban movement to and from the city of Al-Sheher permanently.
On April 10,  the Yemeni governorate of Shabwa ordered the security forces to close the borders with the province of Hadhramout.
On May 11, the Yemeni authorities in Aden banned movement to and from the city, with the exception of the transport of goods.
On May 24, regional authorities in Yemen's Marib province closed all entry points to the province.
On March 16th, Houthi authorities said they had closed land borders with government-controlled parts of Yemen for two weeks except to goods traffic.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided that visits to patients should be generally prohibited in all public and private hospitals and restricted to first-degree relatives.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided that prison visits and reformatories are prohibited and restricted to first-degree relatives.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: In Aden, Yemen, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) announced a three-day, 24-hour curfew from midnight on April 29.

description: On May 6, Houthi authorities in Yemen announced a 24-hour closure of select neighborhoods in areas of Sanaa under their control.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: On May 11, the Yemeni province of Hodeidah approved to form an operations room and committees at the district, areas levels, as well as field teams to coordinate with the relevant authorities, especially in the health and security aspects.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: In Yemen, the Higher Committee for Combating Epidemics approved the formation of a technical committee at the level of each province headed by the province governor and composed by members of the local authorities.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On May 5, health Minister Dr. Nasser Ba’oum said the government, with support from the King Salman Relief and Humanitarian Action Center, has allocated 580 million Yemeni riyals (nearly $900,000*) to authorities in all non-Houthi-controlled governorates and 500 million rials (about $770,000) to the Aden branch of the Central Bank of Yemen, to be distributed to health facilities.
type_text: Economic policy - to be coded as such

description: The Yemeni Ministry of Health approved the allocation of an “emergency budget” of one billion Yemeni riyals ($4 million) to support the health sector and enable it to implement the precautionary and preventative measures to protect the country from the spread of the coronavirus.
type_text: Economic policy - allocation of a budget

description: On April 11, an awareness campaign to face the COVID-19 was launched in the Yemeni province of Taiz.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: In Sanaa, Yemen, The General Administration of Medical and Social Services at the Interior Ministry has implemented a medical hygiene and awareness campaign on May 10 in Habra and Elaya Police Stations to improve their inmates conditions.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 11, the Technical Committee to confront Corona in Rayma province in Yemen approved the formation of community committees at the districts and villages levels to intensify community awareness of the dangers of the virus and ways to prevent it.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On May 19, the Industry Office in Sanaa province in Yemen led a field campaign targeting shops, malls and commercial markets to compel them to put up posters of health instructions issued by the Ministry of Health.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 31st, the emergency committee in the Yemeni province of Taiz approved the conduction of awareness-raising workshops on defining the procedures of quarantine in homes.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On June 3rd, the Elimination of illiteracy program in Amran province in Yemen organized a training workshop to raise awareness on the virus.

enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 3rd, an awareness workshop on precautionary measures the Corona virus was organized by the Technical Committee for Fighting Epidemics in al-Hali district in Hodeidah province, Yemen.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: In Yemen, the Minister of Religious Endowments and Guidance was instructed by the Higher Ministerial Committee for Epidemic Control to take advantage of its capabilities, including mosque preachers, to educate the community about the Corona virus and ways to prevent it.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Anyone exhibiting NCoV symptoms may be subjected to a quarantine.
Yemen imposed home-quarantine for a period of fourteen days to arrivals from 12 international countries, “China, South Korea, Italy, Iran, Japan, Kuwait, Bahrain, UAE, USA, Palestine and France.”
On April 10th, the governor of the Yemeni province Hadhramout announced that the workers at Al-Sheher Port - where the first corona case was identify- will abide by a quarantine for two weeks.
On March 17th, the Yemeni Ministry of Youth and Sports announced the suspension of youth and sports activities in federations and clubs for one month.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen has decided to oblige owners of small, medium and large buses to provide sterilizers and disinfectants to all passengers.
On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to require Shops, restaurants, buffets, and hotels to provide sterilizers and disinfectants to customers
On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to only allow Qat markets if they are moved to open places to prevent crowding in the capital Sanaa.
On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to close hairdresser and beauty shops until further notice.

On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to obligate shaving shops not to allow more than three customers to be present in them, with providing disinfection tools and obliging the hairdressers to wear gags, cover, and gloves while shaving and sterilizing the shaving tools.
On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to reduce the number of employees in the private and mixed sectors by 80 per cent.

On March 22, the National Salvation Government in Yemen decided to obligate banks, exchange shops and companies to provide the necessary sterilizers and disinfectants to customers, with a guard assigned to an ATM machine, to sterilize the hands of ATM users before and after using them.

On March 26th, the local authority in Hajjah province in Yemen, with the participation of the security services, implemented a campaign to close down the city's markets and offered the following alternatives to these markets : the distribution of vendors and selling stands to a number of squares in the city.

On March 26th, the local authority in Hajjah province in Yemen, with the participation of the security services, implemented a campaign to close down the city's markets and offered the following alternatives to these markets : the distribution of vendors and selling stands to a number of squares in the city.
On April 10, the Governor of the Yemeni governorate Hadhramaut decided to shut down public markets.
In Aden, Yemen, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) announced the closure of all major shopping centers on April 26 until further notice.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 2nd, the Yemeni Public Health and Population Office closed four private hospitals due to their failure to comply with the terms of infection control and the allocation of isolation departments, and their refusal to receive suspected sick cases.

description:
On March 28, the Yemeni Ministry of Civil Service and Insurance  announced that the work suspension to 80 per cent of the state’s employees, including the elderly and those suffering from chronic diseases, except for the health, security and services sectors would last until June 14th.

 UPDATE: The policy was initially supposed to be revised after 2 weeks, but it wasn't. This new update sets an end date to the policy.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On May 3rd, three hospitals in Aden, Yemen were closed by the Southern Transitional Council (STC) to prevent damage from the coronavirus. The region had not taken adequate precautions against the outbreak and these hospitals had to stop activities because of inefficient equipment.
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Cabinet of Yemen announced the postponement of all official and popular events, conferences, workshops and the reduction of gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On march 21st, the Yemeni Ministry of Endowments and Guidance announced the suspension of Friday prayers in mosques as well as Holy Quran classes in mosques and outside.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 25, the Houthi authorities in Yemen ordered the release of all Baha'i prisoners.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: To help protect prisons from an outbreak of the virus, the Yemeni local authorities in Shabwa governorate released 43 prisoners on March 28 after a review of their individual cases by a committee formed by Shabwa governor Mohammed Saleh Bin Adyo in coordination with the governorate’s chief prosecutor.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On March 29, the prosecutor’s office in the province of Al-Mahra in Yemen released 49 prisoners who had served two thirds of their sentences to ease the overcrowding of prisons. The authorities in Al-Mahra say they have paid 17 million Yemeni riyals, nearly $31 thousand in bonds to secure the release of prisoners in those cases requiring a financial surety that the defendants will reappear if summoned.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 30, the Yemeni governorate Taiz released 37 low-risk central prison inmates.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On March 30, the Yemeni governorate Marib released 62 low-risk prisoners.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On April 1st, the Yemeni governorate Hadhramout released 200 prisoners.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: On April 10, the Governor of the Yemeni governorate Hadhramaut decided to ban all kinds of gatherings.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: In Aden, Yemen, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) announced the suspension of congregational prayers on April 26 until further notice.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, the Yemeni Ministry of Education announced the postponement of the general certificate tests for the basic and secondary stages until further notice.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 6, Houthi authorities in Yemen announced a 24-hour closure for all mosques in Sanaa.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 5, the Higher Ministerial Committee for Combating Epidemics directed authorities in Sana’a governorates to work toward preventing gatherings of more than 20 people.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 5, the Southern Transitional Council (STC) extended the closure of mosques and prayer gatherings for three weeks starting May 6. UPDATE: The suspension of mosques had to be extended or ended. It was extended for three more weeks starting May 6.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Yemen, the Ministry of Planning and International cooperation decided to ban the implementation of all events, training courses and activities for international organizations for a period of two weeks, subject to renewal.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)
